item.title: Atomic Attributes in Local-First Sync
item.description:
When we set out to build device-sync in Muse, we had a very strict requirement at the outset: it should be local-first.

Most apps work by storing all of your data on the server, and send only little bits of it to each device as you use it. Then, if a document is modified on two devices at once causing a conflict, the server is the mediator to choose the winner.

With local-first sync, the world gets much more complicated. Every device you use contains a full copy of your data. If you edit the same document from multiple devices, there is no server to mediate which device wins. Instead, both devices get a full copy of each other‚Äôs changes, and they need to independently resolve to the same state.

I type on a macbook pro keyboard, and it seems to be from how I turn my wrist to reach the backspace key in particular (we‚Äôre not all perfect typists!).

I attribute my lack of pain so far to a combination of luck and possibly my hand position when typing. Instead of twisting my wrist to have my hands straight on the keyboard, I keep my wrists straight which leaves my fingers tilted on the keyboard. I ran into something interesting when working last night that wasn‚Äôt immediately obvious to me at first. It‚Äôs an alternate way to calculate the product of any two numbers.

I first noticed something was going on when I squared a number and then compared it to the product of numbers on either side of the original number:

5 * 5 = 25
6 * 4 = 24 (1 from 25)
7 * 3 = 21 (3 from 24)
8 * 2 = 16 (5 from 21)
9 * 1 = 9 (7 from 16)

If you subtract each result from the one before it, you see the series: 1, 3, 5, 7. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs interesting, I‚Äôm increasing the distance between the two numbers, and the result keeps changing by 2 also, I wonder if there‚Äôs something to that. Maybe I just got lucky, and this is something odd about 5*5 in particular. So I tried the same process, but started with 6*6, or 8*8 and got the same result.

item.title: The undocumented life of jQuery‚Äôs .append()
item.description:
Related: The undocumented life of JavaScript‚Äôs parentNode property ‚Äì Internet Explorer edition!

Did you know that .append() sometimes moves the nodes you pass into it, and other times clones them? This undocumented behavior may cause you some grief if you‚Äôre assuming the first, but seeing the second.

If you‚Äôre appending to more than 1 node, then jQuery clones the input and then appends the clones to each of the selected items. If you‚Äôre appending to just 1 node, then jQuery does not clone the input, but instead moves the item to that place in the document. These two behaviors can leave you with significantly different results.
